attributes.action: Prohibit the unsolicited delivery of plastic bags
attributes.background: The Government should prohibit the delivery of plastic bags, where these have not been requested. Many charities bulk mail plastic bags, for use to give donations, to households across the country. This contributes to harm against the environment, and can also be a risk to pets.
attributes.additional_details:
The world is trying to reduce its use of single-use plastic, and the British public are now charged for single-use carrier bags in supermarkets. However on an almost daily basis some charities post single-use plastic bags through people's doors, which are unsolicited. This is bad for the environment and a risk to pets.
 
This is at odds with the charge on plastic bags in supermarkets and should be addressed, both to reduce nuisance mail and to protect the environment.

departments.name: Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport

attributes.action: Require products containing plastic to be clearly labelled
attributes.background: Legislate to mandate that, if applicable, products prominently displays that the product contains plastic. Currently some products state if the packaging itself contains plastic, but not the product. Many products contain plastic and there is no mention of that at all. #WarOnPlastic
attributes.additional_details: Plastic is a scourge of the environment. It permeates food, beauty and hygiene products with the consumer not being informed of its presence. Most tea bags, wet wipes, facial scrubs and coffee cups contain plastic, with the consumer often none the wiser. People should be told so that they can make an informed choice about purchase and about disposal.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Allow TV Licence payers to make voluntary additional payments
attributes.background: To enable the BBC to attract extra, voluntary income from TV Licence payers by allowing an optional, extra payment to be made. The standard TV Licence fee would apply to all, but Additional options would be presented to make a voluntary donation, of any amount.
attributes.additional_details: The BBC is an invaluable public service. That said, the Government is making informed budgetary choices in a challenging economic environment. While many struggle, many have the funds to make an extra payment for a service that they value. By giving the TV Licensing authority the opportunity to collect extra donations, the BBC could benefit from additional income, and the Government would gain insight into the level of consumer support for the TV Licence.

departments.name: Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport

attributes.action: Legally ban the consumption of alcohol in the workplace
attributes.background: In light of recent news events and it currently being up to employers what alcohol policies to have in the workplace, I feel it is time to bring the issue of drinking in the workplace into the 21st century and formally ban alcohol consumption both at work and in all work spaces.
attributes.additional_details:
The Government has legislated to ban smoking in many workplaces and public spaces in the name of public health.
 
Alcohol consumption has many detrimental effects including diminishing the ability to make decisions and increasing risk-taking behaviour and the list can go on.
 
As with smoking, alcohol has no place in a modern work place environment therefore legislation is needed to formally ban it in all workplace situations. This ban shouldn't affect customers in hospitality settings.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Test all schoolchildren in England weekly for Covid-19
attributes.background: To reopen schools safely, we ask the government to introduce weekly Covid testing of pupils. The Children’s Commissioner for England and the Royal Society's DELVE group have said routine testing is an essential, cost-effective way to prevent transmission and keep our communities safe.
attributes.additional_details: Asymptomatic cases account for 40% of community Covid transmission, and possibly more among school-age children. In September, many children will spend the day in 'bubbles' of up to 240 children with no social distancing. Without regular testing, many will contract the virus unknowingly, putting their loved ones at risk. Families, especially those with vulnerable members, are having to face the anxiety of sending children into a school environment.

departments.name: Department for Education

attributes.action: Change the law to allow an individual to have a pets ashes buried with them
attributes.background: The current law prevents individuals from having a beloved pet's ashes buried with them.   I believe the law should be changed to allow this
attributes.additional_details:
There are many people who only have their pets and no family and want their pets (family) to remain with them after death.  It is just as heartbreaking losing a loved pet to some, as it is to lose a family member and I believe there would be no threat to the environment to allow this.
Those who have never had a partner or children can look to a pet as the only love they ever had and I believe it would give them a greater peace of mind if they knew they would always be together.

attributes.action: MPs to wear facemasks in debating chamber unless they are speaking
attributes.background: Change the rules within the house as an example to the wider population they should wear face masks, unless they are speaking.
attributes.additional_details: Social distancing must be observed at all times to set a good example to the public, and maintain a covid safe environment.

departments.name: Cabinet Office

attributes.action: Reunite Golcar With Rail by putting in a new train station
attributes.background: I want the Government to put a train station in Golcar as it should be better for the environment and better for the Golcar people. It would help people that need to travel to work that do not have a car.
attributes.additional_details:
Golcar as a community would benefit from a train station as it would mean that there would be easy access to Leeds and Manchester which should benefit the environment as it would mean that there should not be as many cars on the road. 

With there being more and more houses being built in Golcar it means that there are more cars on the road but if we were to have a train station there should not be as many cars congesting the roads.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Make all garden fires illegal
attributes.background: Stop people burning anything in their garden as it’s bad for the environment / the air we breathe and is a nuisance to neighbours especially people with health problems.
attributes.additional_details: Ask the government to ban all fires in private gardens by making it an offence.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Include sexual assault mitigation in the curriculum, save women from violence
attributes.background: We must fight the crisis that is violence against women. To achieve this, the curriculum in secondary schools must include how to mitigate sexual violence- how to spot warning signs in friends behaviour, how words encourage violence, how to protect others and further means of reducing violence.
attributes.additional_details: Secondary schools are the prime environment to undo the normalisation of violence against women. Some schools host sexual assault awareness weeks but encourage women to 'be careful' rather than teaching others to stop assault. For example, women are taught not to walk alone at night, not to leave drinks unattended at a party. This does not stop the violence! 97% of women have experienced sexual assault or harassment. This must be stopped. We deserve safety, to do nothing is to be complicit.

departments.name: Department for Education

attributes.action: Reduce the period of quarantine from 14 to 10 days on all arrivals to England
attributes.background: I would like the Government to allow everyone arriving into England who does not manifest any symptoms of coronavirus on their arrival and in the next 10 days to be able to leave quarantine after 10 days, while quarantine measures are operational due to the Covid-19 pandemic.
attributes.additional_details:
The Netherlands National Institute for Public Health and the Environment has stated that 99% of contacts of a person who was infected with COVID-19 and later became ill developed COVID-19 symptoms within 10 days after contact.
 
Some of the countries have already implemented a 10-day quarantine, f. e. the Netherlands, Norway, Switzerland. It should make life much easier for people who need to travel to England in the coming months.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Fine businesses who put staff at risk by not enforcing face coverings
attributes.background: Apply a fine to any business who allows people to enter the store without either a face covering, or a valid exemption.
attributes.additional_details: Many businesses are not allowing staff to challenge people not wearing masks or to withhold service. This creates an unsafe environment for staff and customers. It forces employees to work in fear. It is an inconvenience, but required to keep us safe. Staff should be encouraged to challenge people breaking safety rules, not prohibited from doing so. Please sign to keep our loved ones safe at work.

departments.name: Department of Health and Social Care

attributes.action: Ban the manufacture and sale of new cars that are solely powered by fossil fuels
attributes.background: It is well publicised that fossil fuels damage the environment. We already have the technology to reduce emissions by using hybrid and electric cars. The government has pledged to make this happen by 2035. Why not make it happen now?

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Require bold environment warnings on wasteful food and drink packaging.
attributes.background:
All wasteful food and drink packaging should be labelled in a bold red warning triangle "Not Waste-Free".

By wasteful we mean not recyclable nor compostable. The label should be on the front panel.

Waste-free living is what we want, is an Earthshot goal, and should be easy!
attributes.additional_details:
Searching for tiny recycling logos or faint "not currently recycled" excuses, particularly for those with poor eyesight, is a pain! The red triangle will make waste instantly obvious, helping us to (a) bin it correctly, not contaminating other well-sorted material (b) avoid buying it, and (c) push suppliers away from it.
While much packaging today is proudly waste-free, it should become the norm, we should be able to assume it is waste-free unless loud and clear warnings state otherwise.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban export of UK-manufactured pesticides which are banned from use in the UK
attributes.background: We want the UK Government to put an end to the export of UK-manufactured paraquat and other toxic pesticides. These are chemicals banned for use in the UK and 50 other countries due to the immense risks they pose to human health and the environment. The double-standard must end now.
attributes.additional_details:
In 2018 the UK Government permitted the export of over 32,000 tonnes of UK-manufactured banned pesticides, 87% of which are reported to have contained paraquat. With paraquat “one sip can kill”, and evidence is mounting of its numerous long-term health impacts.
 
Studies suggest that almost half of these pesticide exports were sent to low and middle-income countries with far weaker safety regulations. It is irresponsible to assume that these chemicals will be used safely, and it is resulting in countless predictable and preventable deaths.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Fund further research and development into the production of synthetic fuels
attributes.background: Government needs to cut carbon emissions and the development and use of synthetic fuels could help. Synthetic fuels could help make transport carbon neutral so the Government should fund research and development into synthetic fuels that can be used by current car engines without modification.
attributes.additional_details:
The production of synthetic fuels could help make transport carbon neutral, which would help the UK government reach their carbon dioxide emissions target of the Paris Agreement.
 
Developing synthetic fuel that can be used by existing engines without modification would mean that those who enjoy driving petrol/diesel vehicles would be able to continue doing so in a way that won't threaten the environment.
 
Refueling a car is much more time-efficient than electric cars, and much of the electricity supply used to charge electric vehicles is still produced by fossil fuel power stations.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Allow soft play centres to open under Tier 3 restrictions
attributes.background: Soft play centres should be grouped alongside gyms and allowed to remain open under tier 3 restrictions from December, as long as they are shown to be Covid safe.
attributes.additional_details: Soft play centres are there to allow children and babies to exercise and develop in a secure and safe environment. The tier 3 restrictions are going to force these places to close permanently if something isn't done soon to save them.

departments.name: Cabinet Office

attributes.action: Allow the sale of nicotine e-liquids in bottles greater than 10 ml.
attributes.background: I would like the government to change the law or regulation that prohibits the sale of nicotine-containing e-liquid in bottles greater than 10ml due to the negative environmental impact this has.
attributes.additional_details: As a society, it is important that we reduce our single-use plastic waste. 5.5% of Britons over the age of 18 vape which means that millions of people are buying e-liquids sold in only 10ml bottles. We would save a lot of plastic waste by allowing people to purchase nicotine-containing e-liquids in bottles greater than 10ml (say 100ml) as this would result in a lower plastic to volume ratio which would result in less plastic waste damaging our environment and polluting our oceans.

departments.name: Department of Health and Social Care

attributes.action: Legislate to ban commercial wooden pallets treated with highly toxic chemicals
attributes.background: We ask the Government to ban all commercial wooden pallets which are treated with highly toxic chemicals. There are other eco-friendly pallets available, and there is no justification why any industry should still be using these wooden pallets for logistical transport and distribution.
attributes.additional_details:
People may think wooden pallets are safe to burn domestically, but PM2.5 emissions are one of the most dangerous pollutants to human health. Banning wooden pallets treated with toxic chemicals should benefit the environment, public health and NHS.

More for information see the links below:

https://www.blf.org.uk/sites/default/files/Ambient%20air%20pollution_levelling%20up%20lung%20health.pdf

https://www.london.gov.uk/sites/default/files/pm2.5_in_london_october19.pdf

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Prohibit transactions in cryptocurrencies in the UK
attributes.background: Legislate to prohibit the payment by or acceptance of cryptocurrencies by UK resident businesses or individuals, and require UK regulators (the FCA and PRA) to prohibit transactions by UK financial institutions in cryptocurrencies such as Bitcoin.
attributes.additional_details: Cryptocurrencies have no intrinsic value and can be a destabilising influence on society, and often used for criminal activity. Banning crypto transactions in the UK would impede criminals that rely on these currencies, and could also affect faith in the currency and so lead to a fall in prices, reducing the wealth and power of those holding cryptos. Cryptos are in no way essential to legitimate citizens and businesses, and the ‘mining’ of cryptos is harmful to the environment.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Increase Environment Agency funding for environmental protection
attributes.background: Government funding for the Environment Agency’s environmental protection work has fallen from about £170m in 2009-10 to a low of £76m in 2019-20, and £94m last year. I want the overnment to increase funding in this area to 2009-10 levels at least, if not more to address years of low funding.
attributes.additional_details:
The Environment Agency has a large budget but we believe not enough of this is being directed towards protecting or improving the environment.
 
Government grants to the agency rose from £880m to £1.05bn over the past two years, and money for flood operations has steadily increased. But Government funding for the agency’s environmental protection work was £94m last year. Work such as attending pollution incidents must not be deprioritised.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban the use of advertising in virtual and augmented reality
attributes.background: New virtual and augmented reality products, such as VR gaming headsets and enhanced reality glasses, could give advertisers new, invasive access to children and the vulnerable. Until more research has been done on its safety, the Government should ban advertising in these immersive, virtual worlds.
attributes.additional_details: Virtual and augmented reality technology creates an immersive, multisensory environment. However, it offers advertisers new and unprecedented access to these virtual worlds, which users (as the name suggests) are encouraged to treat as an enriched kind of reality. The psychological effect of this newly invasive access, notably to children and vulnerable people, remains unknown. Banning advertising in VR will help these unique spaces to stay safe and healthy, rather than coercive and manipulative.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Create an alternative education provision for neuro-diverse children and teens
attributes.background: Create an outside, farmstead type alternative to conventional education with a focus on vocational and life skills. Teaching children to grow, harvest and prepare their own food. Basic English and maths onsite and therapeutic interventions where necessary. Focus on environment and sustainability.
attributes.additional_details: Proactive strategy to avoid the sudden increase in SEMH difficulties in neurodiverse children and teens who are misunderstood and as such treated as 'undesirables' leading to plummeting self esteem and a need for connection (often found though crime or drugs). A community based approach where everyone is 'understood', strengths and success are the focus and practical 'outside the box' thinking is celebrated and nurtured. Some of our most successful entrepreuneurs have ADHD but the amount of children I see, as SenCo, hit rock bottom through lack of understanding in the educational system is profound.

departments.name: Department for Education

attributes.action: Let tattooists back to work now
attributes.background: I’m a self employed tattooist and I need to be working to survive as thousands of others in the industry need to be also. I think that our sector should be reviewed and put into a separate category rather than health and beauty.
attributes.additional_details: We work in clean sterile environments with training in handling blood-borne diseases and viruses. Tattooists working in studios that have been trained know how to work in a sterile clean and safe environment. I think that the decision to stop the tattoo industry from working should be reviewed as it can’t be compared to hair dressing for instance. We see two customers maximum a day usually and the working environment is one of the most safe and clean.

departments.name: Cabinet Office

attributes.action: Ensure that there is suitable affordable housing available for all young people
attributes.background: According to Centrepoint research 110,000 young people asked their local authority for help with homelessness last year - this needs to change. We call on the Government to provide local authorities with ringfenced funds to provide all young people in need somewhere suitable and affordable to live.
attributes.additional_details: No young person should be forced to live on the streets or to sofa surf. Young people need a safe and secure environment in which they can thrive and develop. Austerity cuts have removed a lot of that security and has made some areas a lot more deprived. The Government needs to address these issues that they are responsible for.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Donate any surplus or unsuitable NHS masks to the public
attributes.background: Government has spent a lot of money to buy 50 million face masks which are not up to NHS standards for use in a high risk environment. If they are otherwise fit for use, the Government could give them away for free to people on low income for general use.
attributes.additional_details: It would be a smart move to give these masks, and any other that NHS and social care workers can’t use away to vulnerable people or those on low income, who cannot afford to buy/use fresh masks all the time.

departments.name: Department of Health and Social Care

attributes.action: Abolish the Arts Council
attributes.background: Abolish the Arts Council, and do not transfer its responsibilities to other government departments.
attributes.additional_details: Government finances are very tight, spending on vital government services is being constrained and taxes are being increased. The Arts Council is impossible to justify in this environment. Those who enjoy the arts should make their own decisions to provide funding.

departments.name: Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport

attributes.action: Add fire awareness to the national curriculum
attributes.background: The Government should require schools to teach children about the impact of fire on the environment, particularly moorland, and how it can affect fire services’ ability to respond to other emergencies.
attributes.additional_details: This should make people more aware of the risks of starting fires outdoors, and help to prevent devastating effects on our moorland and the environment as a whole.

departments.name: Department for Education

attributes.action: Require schools to operate a 4 day week
attributes.background: I believe two days is not enough time as a break mentally. Students could use three-days spending time with family since it could improve mental health, help children perform better academically, and lower risk of behavioural problems.
attributes.additional_details: Students with busy schedules can quickly become overwhelmed because they are left with no free time to relax. Stress can cause many serious mental health problems such as: depression, anxiety, and personal disorders. Being surrounded in an environment where students are being put on pressure is normal makes students a vulnerable target to such mental health problems.

departments.name: Department for Education

attributes.action: Reduce working time required for rest breaks
attributes.background: Reduce the length of time before staff are entitled to rest breaks in the workplace from 6 hours.
attributes.additional_details: Working over 6 hours to be entitled to a break in a busy retail environment etc is quite exhausting and I.e.working 9am-3pm with no lunch should not be acceptable

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Stop the supermarkets supplying food from outside Europe.
attributes.background: Ban suppliers from purchasing food from outside Europe in favour of our own farmers. Stop non sensible air miles, stop supporting countries and companies exploiting a low paid workforce. While we eat their crops many starve.
attributes.additional_details:
It’s mad to be buying Asparagus from China. I want you to incentivise British farmers and penalise food that originated from outside Europe.
We should become more self sufficient and stop relying on countries like China. 
Let’s get our manufacturing up, incentivise farmers and create a workforce to be proud of. It will help the environment and create jobs

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Change the law to allow legal supervised injection facilities to reduce deaths.
attributes.background: The uk is in an opiate crisis. There is a lack of support due to stigma or fear of legal action for drug users meaning people are using substances in unsafe environments, sharing needles and overdosing with out prompt medical assistance. This needs to end. We need to provide supervised facilities.
attributes.additional_details: In 2020 there was 4,561 recorded deaths due to drug overdose/ drug poisoning. That’s a 3.8% increase from 2019. 49.6% so 2,263 of these deaths were related to opiates. - Office of national statistics. Supervised facilities would allow quick administration of the drug Naloxone and resuscitation to reverse these affects and allow support to cut down to be more accessible. The centres would not provide drugs just a safe space with support and resuscitation and antidote.

departments.name: Home Office

attributes.action: Ban the selling of computer games codes in physical boxes
attributes.background: I am calling on the UK Government and Parliament to ban the selling of  computer games codes in physical boxes. These codes do not need to be sold physically as they can be purchased online. Banning their sale would be a simple and effective way of reducing excess plastic.
attributes.additional_details:
Walk into any high street retailer or look at any online store that sells computer games and you will see that a large portion of the games they are saying are merely a download code in a plastic case. This makes no sense as the purpose of the case was initially to protect the cartridge or disc inside. Without a physical item inside, the plastic case is just a waste - and the code can be easily purchase in a digital form.
Outlawing the sale of these cases would be a net good for the environment.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Immediate ban on the use of diesel cars and make all public transport free
attributes.background: I want an immediate ban on Diesel engines in the United Kingdom and for public transport to become free.
attributes.additional_details: I want Diesel engines to be banned because they are polluting our earths atmosphere and I think that individual action will not be enough to turn climate change around. Although it may cause some inconvenience there is no point in using the Diesel engines because they are damaging the environment. If you agree me please sign this to create a better earth for our future generations.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Debate on Covid-19 crisis in low income countries and hostile environments
attributes.background: Call for a Global Pandemic Executive to lead a campaign to prevent a Covid-19 crisis as raised by Trauma surgeon Dr David Nott in support of the 34 fragile countries identified by the World Rescue Committee led by David Milliband in the light of the potential catastrophic spread of Covid-19.
attributes.additional_details: Because it is estimated that up to 3 million people could die without support from richer countries such as the UK. There is also a potential impact on the UK and Europe if those affected migrate to safer countries

departments.name: Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office

attributes.action: During lock-down the Government should pay for all NHS staff's travel expenses.
attributes.background: Whilst non-key workers are self isolating, I believe that it is an injustice that NHS staff are required to continue paying for travel to and from work during lock-down. I believe that a sensible compensation would be for the government to subsidise all travel expenses.
attributes.additional_details: Whilst non key workers are either being paid full or 80% of their wages to self isolate and engage in minimal work in a safe environment, it is apparent that NHS do not have this liberty. NHS staff continue to work on the front line whilst risking health of themselves and family. The fact that staff continue to pay travel expenses is an extreme example of financial inequity.

departments.name: Department of Health and Social Care

attributes.action: Ban the release of helium balloons into the environment
attributes.background: Stop organisations from selling helium balloons and swap to environmentally friendly ones
attributes.additional_details: It is not good for the environment and harms animals and local wildlife, eventually the balloons end up in the oceans as microplastics

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We're not sure if you want the Government to ban the release or sale of helium balloons, or both. It's also not clear what environmentally friendly alternatives you would prefer were sold and released.

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

attributes.action: Fund free public transport for all 16-18 year olds in full-time education
attributes.background: Support both the environment and young people by funding transport to and from education and elsewhere.
attributes.additional_details: To ease the burden of the cost of living crisis and help the environment by making it cheaper not to use cars.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Ban fireworks
attributes.background: Ban noisy fireworks and only allow licensed displays
attributes.additional_details: To stop the fear in all pets, people suffering from demetia/altzeimers and autistic children and adults from the noise fireworks cause, to help the environment

rejection.details:
We have published the following petitions, which you might like to sign:

Ban sale of fireworks to the public and limit sales to licensed displays only: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/616868

Reduce the decibel limit on fireworks to 85 decibels, to reduce impact: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/622900

You can find other petitions calling for changes to rules on releasing fireworks here: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions?q=fireworks&state=open

attributes.action: Regulate the fire and security industry.
attributes.background: There’s no law in place to prevent anyone without sufficient training and expertise to go off and setup a business within the fire and security industry so it’s crucial something similar to the SIA is put in to place to correctly regulate the industry.
attributes.additional_details:
People have lost their lives due to incorrectly specified and installed life saving systems. 

Crime is continuing to increase and society is becoming desperate which has seen an increase in burglary and home invasions. 

Families have been put in dangerous situations with incorrectly fitted security systems that fail when they are needed the most. 

We need to have laws in place to protect the consumer from fraud, theft and dangerous environments.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you are concerned about regulation of certain sectors, but it's not clear what new regulation you want the Government to introduce, or who you want this to apply to.

As you note in your petition, the SIA already regulates the private security sector, and there are a range of regulations that cover fire safety.

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

attributes.action: Lift the suspension of rescue dogs & request the resignation of George Eustice.
attributes.background: Following today's heartbreaking decision referring to the continuation of the suspension of Romanian dogs entering the UK we demand the immediate lift of the extension and the immediate resignation of George Eustice, Secretary of State for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs.
attributes.additional_details: We have furnished George Eustice with the relevant requested evidence that there is minimal risk to UK biosecurity from rescue dogs entering the UK from Romania. The welfare of dogs has not been considered in this decision. Hundreds of dogs are losing their lives due to DEFRA assumptions. Their deaths will be brutal & horrifying. Many UK citizens are being denied the right to bring their chosen pet to their homes. Charities are being forced to operate illegally not fulfilling their constitutions

rejection.details:
We have published the following petitions, which you might like to sign:

Exempt charities using IPAFFS from ban on importing animals from Eastern Europe: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/616575

Lift ban on import of rescue animals from Romania, Ukraine, Belarus and Poland: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/616592

We can't accept petitions about appointments, which includes calling for Ministers to resign or be sacked.

attributes.action: Make VAT on fast Ev charging stations same as home ones 5% instead of 20%
attributes.background: The VAT rate of fast Ev chargers is 20% as opposed to the 5% rate for home chargers let's get this in line with home chargers at 5%
attributes.additional_details: So that people without EV stations are not discriminated against. Also to make EV's more attractive to people to switch to electric and help the environment.  Also would help Ev charge providers to get more business therefore investing in better EV charging infrastructure

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition which calls for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/608872

attributes.action: Adopt a phased approach for removing entitlement to use rebated (red) diesel.
attributes.background: Introduce an annual escalator (starting on 1st April 2022) on fuel duty. Viable alternatives are simply not available or reasonably accessible. As a fiscal measure an escalator would stimulate more development, time for implementation and provide market ready conditions, whilst preserving businesses
attributes.additional_details: Sectors relying on rebated fuel are critical to the UK economy, society and the environment. Construction, Waste and other sectors will be seriously impacted by the removal of entitlement and will face catastrophic consequences in terms of ability to trade and provide essential services. The landscape is exceptionally different now compared to when the hike was announced, with ongoing issues flowing from; Covid, Brexit, driver shortages, economic recovery, energy crisis and consumer inflation

rejection.details:
We have published the following petitions, which you might like to sign:

Allow the Events industry to continue using red rebated fuels after 1 April 2022: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/599254

Delay removal of red diesel entitlement from the construction industry: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/607637

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Mandatory insurance,competent use and tax fee for cyclists and horse riders
attributes.background:
Implementation of mandatory insurance coverage for cyclists and horse riders to cover possible damage to property. 
Proof of competent handling of horse riders to use the public highway
A small mandatory fee contributing to maintaining road conditions
attributes.additional_details: With the changes to the highway code giving cyclists and horse riders more right of way, it would create more of a dangerous environment for all parties. Cyclists and horse riders should be required to have valid insurance coverage incase of damage to property where blame is proven. horse riders required to prove competent rider skills on the public highway, such as all other road users, and a small annual fee contributing to maintaining public highway conditions

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for a similar action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/607217

attributes.action: Pause the determination of all solar developments that are over 40 Megawatts.
attributes.background: Government should review the regulatory framework which is in place to manage solar developments, to ensure it considers a broader range of factors than the current National Planning Policy Framework (NPPF), which is insufficient in preventing speculative development of our landscape.
attributes.additional_details: No solar development should be approved until their impact on the environment and biodiversity is understood. There is currently a clear policy conflict within Government.  On the one hand, Government seeks to protect and enhance our domestic production to maintain food security and recognises the pivotal role of farm land as a carbon sink. On the other, Government is encouraging the indiscriminate growth of renewable energy production. Growth of solar farms must be subject to better regulation.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We're not sure exactly what you'd like the Government or Parliament to do. We understand you are concerned about the impact that solar farms might have on the environment and would like to see changes to the regulations, but it's not clear if you want all approval of solar farms stopped or if you want changes to the regulations, and if so, what regulations on solar farms would you like the Government to action.

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

attributes.action: Recognition of natural post-Covid19 immunity as vaccines exemption
attributes.background: Natural immunity is how humanity survived and adapted to the environment over millennia. Its efficacy, durability and adaptability is the gold standard to which pharmaceuticals aim to compare with. Historically, NO treatment is offered to a person AFTER they recovered from their illness.
attributes.additional_details:
By signing this petition:
1. we expect that the decision-makers acknowledge, following a thorough scientific review, the naturally acquired Covid19 immunity of an increasing percentage of the population thus freeing ourselves from needless waves of restrictions 
2. we say NO green pass is required because people are immune either naturally (everyone will meet with the virus eventually) or through vaccination

attributes.action: Allow parents back into nurseries and early learning facilities.
attributes.background:
The restriction on parents entering nurseries and early learning facilities has been kept in place when other businesses' restrictions have been eased. 
Remove the current Covid restriction that prevents parents and guardians from entering nurseries and early learning centers.
attributes.additional_details: Currently, parents are not allowed to enter the building where their child is being cared for. This lack of transparency and visibility is driving down the standard of care which will ultimately be putting our children at risk. Parents are unable to witness the interactions between their child and their caregiver and with other children. This is no longer acceptable when parents and children are allowed to interact in other environments like soft plays, sports centres and clubs.

rejection.details: We understand you're concerned about parents being able to visit early years and other childcare settings. However there is no current Government guidance banning such visits, so it's not clear what you want the Government to do differently. Decisions about entering such settings are matters for individual childcare settings, so if you wish to complain about the visit policy at a particular local setting, you could contact them.

attributes.action: Ban Ofsted inspections until Covid is truly over.
attributes.background: The government have given Ofsted money to ramp up inspections. However, due to Covid there is already an enormous amount of pressure on teachers to catch children up. Countless teachers and headteachers are now suffering with their mental health. Ofsted offered no support during Covid.
attributes.additional_details: School staff are humans too. They worked throughout the pandemic, whilst Ofsted did not. Not only is Covid still very real, causing staff to have time off but now the Omicrom variant is about to add more pressure. Not only are Teachers having time off, headteachers of decades are quitting due to Ofsted. Finally, children need time to catch up and recover and learn to be in a school environment. Ofsted are so detached from schools, they need a full inspection themselves before being allowed back.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for a similar action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/589622

attributes.action: Remove cannabis from the MoDA and recognise it as a therapeutic supplement.
attributes.background: Id like the government to follow the science when it considers the legality of cannabis. I'd like for them to stop ignoring all the reports and studies that show that cannabis is a vital supplement. It is time to promote Cannabis and build with hemp to heal not only our people, but the environment.
attributes.additional_details: It doesn't make sense to police that which you recognised as medicine in 2018. You police it under the guise of public safety but have created an illegal cannabis trade that ruins lives. You stop people healing organically with cannabis in favour of pharmaceuticals. You let children die from epileptic fits while preventing their parents from growing the treatment that works in the garden. while you do that, you profit from being the largest supplier of cannabis in the world. Follow the science.

rejection.details:
You may wish to sign these petitions calling for related actions:

Legalise cannabis for recreational and medicinal use
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/598861

Allow people with medicinal cannabis prescriptions to grow their own cannabis
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/596416

attributes.action: Stop the sale of fireworks in supermarkets to the general public
attributes.background: Animals become stressed, the environment is impacted by more carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide and nitrogen being released into the air and thousands of people put extra strain on the NHS each year to treat firework-related injuries. And this is ALL AVOIDABLE.
attributes.additional_details:
Bonfire night has become firework month due to the commercialisation of fireworks. 

The irony of people wanting their children to see them in their garden at the risk of their future survival on this planet beggars belief.

If a neighbour has a party with loud music, the police can understandably be called. Yet neighbours can let off fireworks all evening and late into the night to no consequence. 

It is anti-social and has to stop.

rejection.details:
You may wish to sign this petition calling for a similar action: 

Make fireworks illegal to buy, with the exception of public displays.:
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/591501
